Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Phonological Prediction in Spoken Language Processing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Speech unfolds rapidly in time, yet native speakersâ€™ comprehension is generally accurate and efficient. Previous research suggests that one reason why language processing seems to be so effortless and robust is that language users can use context to predict upcoming language input. It is generally agreed that semantic and morpho-syntactic features of a highly expected word can be pre-activated in such predictive language processing. However, there is an ongoing debate about whether the phonological form of a predictable word can also be routinely pre-activated in real-time sentence processing. This project addresses this debate by exploiting the phenomena of anticipatory tonal variations. The results of this study will advance our knowledge on the role of anticipatory tonal variations in spoken-word recognition and speech processing, and on phonological form pre-activation in predictive language processing. This will in turn inform our understanding of the cognitive process in language perception.<br/><br/>This project first examines how anticipatory tonal variation cues can facilitate tonal prediction of an upcoming word in speech perception using eye-tracking technique. Then, the study will examine whether listeners can pre-activate the tonal form of a predictable word by measuring their brain responses to the preceding word using electroencephalography (EEG) technique. Crucially, the expected word in some experimental conditions will be substituted by an unexpected one that shares or does not share the tonal form with the expected word, so the anticipatory tonal variation cues in the preceding word is either concordant or incompatible with the tone of the expected word. The guiding hypothesis is that if the tonal form of the expected word can be pre-activated, there should be larger amplitude modulation of event-related potentials (ERPs) to the preceding word when the unexpected word and the predicted word differ in tone; however, if there is little or no phonological form pre-activation, there should be little or no ERP amplitude modulation prior to encountering the unexpected word<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The findings of this project contribute to resolving the dispute over phonological form pre-activation in the literature by showing that the lack of pre-nominal ERP effects does not necessarily deny phonological form pre-activation; rather, it could indicate that the cues presented in the pre-target words are not a reliable indicator of the phonological form of the target words. This clarification is important for theories of predictive language processing because one of the key and most widely cited pieces of empirical evidence for linguistic prediction comes from the original findings of DeLong et al. (2005) that the highly specific phonological form of a word, rather than merely its semantic or morpho-syntactic features, can be pre-activated. While failures to replicate the DeLong et al. findings were used to argue against phonological form pre-activation or even the important role of prediction in language processing, the current project offers empirical evidence to reconcile the divergent findings.
This dissertation project also has methodological implications for studies on predictive language processing. The results of Study 3 established that when the cues in pre-target words match the predicted words, the pre-activation level of the expected words gets increased. This is manifested in an ERP component belonging to the N400 family that both demonstrates the benefits of confirmed predictions (i.e., reduced amplitude) and the costs of disconfirmed predictions (i.e., enhanced amplitude). This provides another piece of empirical evidence to support the prediction account of the N400 and thus supports the view that prediction is an important mechanism of language comprehension. 
This dissertation project also fills a gap in research on anticipatory coarticulation in spoken-word recognition by demonstrating that, like segmental coarticulation, anticipatory tonal variation cues such as third tone sandhi can also facilitate spoken-word recognition and enable phonological prediction of a following word. This provides further evidence that the systematic and explicable acoustic variances of speech sounds in connected speech can facilitate, rather than disrupt, the recognition of spoken words.
